TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Typic Paleustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Maes cobbly loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--2 inches; forest litter in various stages of decomposition.
A1--0 to 2 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) cobbly loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; moderate thin platy structure parting to moderate fine granular; soft, very friable; many very fine and fine roots; many fine and medium pores; 15 percent cobbles and 5 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
A2--2 to 7 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) cobbly sandy loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, friable; many very fine, fine and few medium roots; many medium, few very fine and fine pores; 15 percent cobbles and 5 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); clear irregular boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
A&B--7 to 16 inches; (A2) very pale brown (10YR 7/4) very cobbly sandy loam, strong brown (10YR 5/6) moist; and (B2t) blocks of yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) cobbly sandy clay, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak medium granular structure; soft, friable; common very fine and fine, few medium and coarse roots; many fine pores; 25 percent cobbles, 10 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); gradual wavy boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
B&A--16 to 35 inches; (B2t) yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) very cobbly sandy clay, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; and (A2) very pale brown (10YR 7/4) very cobbly sandy loam, strong brown (10YR 5/6) moist; weak medium and fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine, fine and medium roots; common fine pores; 30 percent cobbles, 20 percent gravel; moderately thick clay films on peds; slightly acid (pH 6.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (15 to 20 inches thick)
B21t--35 to 57 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) very cobbly sandy clay, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; thick clay films on peds and patchy clay films on rock fragments; few fine and medium roots; few fine pores; 35 percent cobbles and 15 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.2); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 20 inches thick)
B22t--57 to 67 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/8) very cobbly sandy clay, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; thin patchy clay films on peds and rock fragments; few fine roots; 50 percent cobbles and 10 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.2).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Taos County, New Mexico; AMS Photo 3028, SE1/4 SE1/4 section 25, T.7N., R.14E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 40 to 44 degrees F. and the mean summer soil temperature is warmer than 47 degrees F.  The solum is 40 to 80 inches thick.  The upper boundary of the argillic horizon is less than 24 inches below the mineral surface.  Angular rock fragments in the major part of the solum range from 35 to 70 percent.
The A1 horizon has value of 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  It is loam or fine sandy loam and has 10 to 15 percent cobbles and 5 to 10 percent gravel.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 6 through 8 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  It is sandy loam, fine sandy loam, or loam and has 10 to 15 percent cobbles and 5 to 10 percent gravel.
The mixed horizons have hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 4 through 8 dry, 2 through 6 moist, and chroma of 2 through 6.  They are mixtures of loam, sandy loam, clay, and sandy clay and have 15 to 30 percent cobbles and 10 to 20 percent gravel.
The B2t horizon has hue of 10YR through 5YR, value of 4 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 6.  It is sandy clay, clay, silty clay, or heavy clay loam and has 25 to 60 percent cobbles, 10 to 60 percent gravel and 10 to 15 percent stones.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Diamante, Jaroso, Mascarenas and Trampas series.  Diamante and Trampas soil lack mixed A&B and B&A horizons.  Jaroso and Mascarenas soils have cryic temperature.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Maes soils are on smooth mountain sides and benches.  Slopes typically range from 30 to 80 percent.  The soils formed in material weathered from shale and sandstone of the Pennsylvanian Formation.  Elevation ranges from 8,000 to 10,500 feet.  The annual precipitation is between 25 to 35 inches per year with peak periods during the winter and late summer.  The average annual temperature is 44 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Derecho and Etoe soils and the competing Jaroso and Trampas soils.  Derecho soils lack A&B and B&A horizons and  have an epipedon marginal to a mollic epipedon.  Etoe soils are loamy, skeletal.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for timber production, grazing, wildlife habitat, recreation and watershed.  Native vegetation is mainly Douglas fir, white fir, scattered ponderosa pine, aspen, snowberry and various grasses.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas of north and north central New Mexico.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taos Area, New Mexico, 1976.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The classification is tentative, pending collection of supporting data.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
